title: 103_hr82
content: Restoration of deduction for interest on educational loans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for the deduction of interest on qualified educational loans. A qualified educational loan is defined as indebtedness provided through specific programs or by certain tax-exempt organizations. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for the deduction of interest on qualified educational loans incurred to pay educational expenses within a reasonable period before or after the indebtedness is incurred. The amount of interest eligible for deduction is reduced by a phaseout provision. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is subject to a phaseout based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The applicable dollar amount and phaseout range vary depending on the filing status. The deduction is only allowable for the first 48 months the loan is in repayment status. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is subject to a phaseout based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. It is only allowable for the first 48 months the loan is in repayment status, and applies to qualified tuition and related expenses. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is subject to a phaseout based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. For taxable years after 1994, the $40,000 and $60,000 amounts are adjusted for inflation using the cost-of-living adjustment under section 1(f)(3). If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $50, it is rounded to the nearest multiple. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is subject to a phaseout based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1993, but only with respect to loans the first required payment on which is after that date. The amount is rounded to the nearest multiple of $50.
